With great sadness, we share with you the death of Mr. Horace (Whit) Whitman. He was an advocate for public education, who served VUSD students as a Governing Board member for nine years. He had been battling depression for some time and took his own life.

Mr. Whitman was committed to supporting the Vacaville Unified School District and leaves behind a legacy of love for students and support of public education.

We send our deepest condolences to Mr. Whitman’s family and the community. Mr. Whitman’s family will remain in our thoughts and prayers during this difficult time.

If you or anyone you know is showing signs of depression, especially during these uncertain times, please reach out and ask for help. The suicide hotline number is 800-273-8255.

For signs to look for: https://www.nami.org/About-Mental-Illness/Common-with-Mental-Illness/Risk-of-Suicide

The #BeThe1To website goes into more depth about what to do if a loved one is at risk:https://www.bethe1to.com/bethe1to-steps-evidence/

Extreme heat presents dangerous conditions for many including the most vulnerable. Here are steps to protect yourself and loved ones:

- Avoid outdoor activities during the hottest part of the day, generally, 10 am to 6 pm

- If you must be outside, take frequent breaks in the shade or air conditioning

- Stay hydrated

- Check on elderly or vulnerable family members and neighbors

- Wear light-weight clothing

-Never leave children or animals alone in a vehicle

A heat wave is upon us. Temperatures are expected to exceed 100 degrees several days in a row. As a result, the City of Vacaville is opening McBride Senior Center as a cooling center to provide residents respite from the heat. McBride Senior Center will be open from noon until 8 pm on Friday, August 14 through Sunday, August 16. It is located at 91 Town Square Place, Vacaville, CA 95688. City staff will continue to monitor the weather and will keep the cooling center open beyond Sunday as necessary.

Water will be provided. Due to the pandemic, COVID safety protocol will be in place

The excessive heat is expected to last until next Friday, August 21. Please follow these safety tips to stay cool during the heat wave:

- Stay hydrated – drink plenty of water.
- Limit strenuous outdoor activity. Find shade
- Check on the elderly, sick, and those without air conditioning
- Never leave children or pets unattended in vehicles
- Be mindful of hot pavement when walking your pets – consider protection for their paws

CDC: STEPS YOU CAN TAKE IF A FAMILY MEMBER GETS ILL- Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (e.g. tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks)
In the bedroom/bathroom dedicated for an ill person: consider reducing cleaning frequency to as-needed (e.g., soiled items and surfaces) to avoid unnecessary contact with the ill person.
As much as possible, an ill person should stay in a specific room and away from other people in their home, following home care guidance.
The caregiver can provide personal cleaning supplies for an ill person’s room and bathroom, unless the room is occupied by child or another person for whom such supplies would not be appropriate. These supplies include tissues, paper towels, cleaners.
If a separate bathroom is not available, the bathroom should be cleaned and disinfected after each use by an ill person. If this is not possible, the caregiver should wait as long as practical after use by an ill person to clean and disinfect the high-touch surfaces.

We have so many great Mini Clubs! 🤗 Garden is always a favorite and it’s really neat to see how excited the kids are to harvest and make their own food. This morning, a bunch of different greens were harvested from the garden for a salad, which was paired with a fresh raspberry vinaigrette dressing! Yum! 🥬

We also had some fun with eggs! We were gifted some fresh chicken, duck and quail eggs from three parents and the kids were able to crack them open, see the differences and then taste the differences! 🥚🐓

The meal was also served with fresh squeezed lemonade and lemon bars! 🍋

Lastly, the kids worked hard preparing the soil for planting new produce next month! 🤗🌱☀️💦

This energetic ride through a bustling city highlights the wonderful perspective only grandparent and grandchild can share and comes to life through Matt de la Pena’s vibrant text and Christian Robinson’s radiant illustrations.

Wood: During third period today, there was a situation in our administrative office in which one of our Vacaville School Resource Officer (SRO) was called for additional support for a student in crisis. Several police cars responded and parked at the front of the school before entering the campus to assist. Around the same time, one of our fire alarms malfunctioned and became activated. These two situations were coincidental, although many students became worried that there were several police cars on campus at the same time as the false fire alarm.

Unfortunately, student rumors spread during lunchtime that there may have been a threat to the school, or a weapon on campus. We are writing to let our parents and guardians know that there was not a weapon on campus and that these two situations were unrelated and coincidental. All students and staff are safe and in class and we are conducting business as usual at school. If you have any questions or concerns, please call our main office.
